Much of the discontent which is at present strongly expressed about the Government is due to the harsh treatment of the times, which reflected in a reaction of painted rubbers. Many things have recently been spread in the newspapers, in a large set of spirit that will influence the business set up in this journal, the question of who owns what, not counterparts, as they say, on its way out, before any definite number, each reader is likely to be treated according to his name like 90% of the cases decided so far. Now it is very clear that any income can long endure the expected tax burdens and nothing substantial even, must go to contribute towards productive purposes, without being called upon to invest the money considered vital to the economy. In such circumstances an immediate panic takes place being somehow brought under control by the merchants. ITEMS OF INTEREST
TERRITORIAL NEWS.
THE VERY LATEST NEWS.

REGINA.
From the Leader, sept. 28.
Mr. Robert Stephenson, having finished his inspection of the Colonization Company at Wascana, left yesterday afternoon for Winnipeg, where he is now going to reside.
Several of our farmers have been working hard at their farms, and again in town, but few have had time to get much threshing done yet. We believe that there is plenty of work ready for the men who have been working enough.

We are informed that Mr. John Maclean, who has been here recently, has completed the purchase from the C.P.R. of about 10 acres of land about 10 miles S.E. of Regina and that he is contemplating planting it with wheat, which he expects will be ready for cropping in the spring.
The price of Minnesota Wheat is said to be $5 per bushel, while the price of Ojibwa (No. 7) is said to be $4 per bushel. The wheat grown on the government farms, but the raising of wheat on Wascana Passage in Prince Albert is also said to be profitable.

EDMONTON.
From the Bulletin, sept. 28.
A letter from J. Fairey, formerly a resident of Saskatchewan, now residing at the H.B.C. post at Fort Chipewyan, has been received by telegraph. He says that he arrived at Chipewyan on the 1st of June. There was still ice in lake Athabasca, and he was obliged to wait until the ice broke up before he could get back to Edmonton. In order to allow his boat to reach the fort, he was compelled to leave behind him a number of goods for the traders, and he hopes to be able to send them back when he returns.

The federal authorities, on the recommendation of Mr. A. Anderson, Crown Timber Agent, have ordered a large quantity of pine lumber required for the Wat Creek, Black Maud, and Upper Burgess River bridges erected under authority of the North West Mounted Police.

CALGARY.
From the Herald, sept. 28.
War Foster, formerly a bachelor in the town was married last Friday at St. Patrick's Church. The bride was Miss Emily Smith, who has been engaged to him for some time. Foster is now engaged in the lumber business, and is doing well.

The federal authorities, on the recommendation of Mr. A. Anderson, Crown Timber Agent, have ordered a large quantity of pine lumber required for the Wat Creek, Black Maud, and Upper Burgess River bridges erected under authority of the North West Mounted Police.

MANITOBA.
PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE.
From the Review, sept. 29.
The Manitoba Farmers carried off the silver medal at the Eastern Exhibition in addition to high commendation.
A couple of carloads of hardwood have been shipped from the east. It costs about $13 a ton.
The Portage Milling Company received another order for 6,000 sacks of flour from the east. It costs about $13 a ton.
Optics has sent a buyer to Macdonald with instructions to pay Portage prices for what deliveries they can make.

WINNIPEG.
From the Press, sept. 29.
The North Dakota Agricultural Society has been formed. It will take advantage of the rich soil and abundant rainfall.
His Lordship, the Bishop of Rupert, has appointed the Rev. G. G. Murray to the mission of Pembina Springs.
Mr. J. A. Richardson, formerly in charge of the school at Portage la Prairie, has returned to his old home at Portage la Prairie.
Mr. T. Foster, D.D., brother of the late Mr. Foster, has been appointed rector of Trinity Church, St. John's.
Mr. Donald A. Smith, a lawyer, and Mr. George W. Field, a merchant, have joined the firm of Smith & Field.
Mr. Thomas Egan and Mr. Louis Condon have joined the firm of Egan & Condon.
Mr. Thomas Egan and Mr. Louis Condon have joined the firm of Egan & Condon.

OANADIAN.

Lapage Head, N.W.T., Sept. 24.—The party who were lost in their Hall Park tent near Fort Belcher, Da-
kota, that they have recovered three horses but have nothing of the lost
equipment.

Montreal, Sept. 26.—The Grand Trunk railway has just bought a number of old cars which will be used next fall.

Toronto, Sept. 26.—Septemps A. Den-
ham was elected president of the aldermen for St. Nicholas ward by filling the vacancy caused by the resignation of his brother, Major Denham, of the Nite express.

Over 150 men left this morning to work on the P. R. at the Rockies.

Hamilton, Sept. 26.—Allard's plan-
ning mill closed this evening at 8:00 o'clock.

The chief attraction at the Central Exhibition is the famous "Great Train Crash" and a troop of Texas cowboys. Owing to very dearth with the ride and the riders, the cowboys will dis-
play their horsemanship.

Ottawa, Sept. 27.—The Committee on the appointment of Dr. Codde of Winnipeg, as medical examiner under the Civil Service Act.

The Manitoba exhibit sent here by the Provincial Fair arrived last night by boat from Winnipeg. It is now in the main building. The potatoes and cabbage are very fine, and the wheat splendid. The committee has done a good deal to correct the erroneous impres-
sions held here as to the fertility of Manitoba soil.

The Canada Company's prize of $100 for best fall wheat was awarded to W. M. J. J. C. Smith of Fairfield Plains, Bruce County.

Kensico, Sept. 27.—The temperance people here are fighting the extension of the Liquor Act as a result of the recent election.

St. John's, Nfld., Sept. 27.—The steamer Briar, from Montreal, was re-
ported here with her propeller broken. It was smashed by collision with ice. She is 372 tons burthen and runs Cape Race to Liverpool. The average of fifteen to twenty passengers per St. John's daily sailing is too low in view of present conditions. The steamer John's report passing large quantities of wood along the coast of Labrador. On Thursday she was reported to have been
seized. The same day, the schooner Lisette was lost, but the crew was saved. Harry Murray, who was the first to be
rescued, says the vessel appeared like a miniature Polar sea, being dotted with twenty-five small bergs.

Narrowsburg, Sept. 27.—A man of notice named Woodman, standing near a switch at Grafton, was killed instantly by a freight train. He was over sixty years old.

Hilliardton, Sept. 27.—An effigy of King Dublin, the temperance lecturer, was burned here.

Montreal, Sept. 27.—F. Manseau, of Canada Co., beer manufacturers, was captured by Mr. Whitney, Wadlow & Co.'s, leather merchant.

Quebec, Sept. 27.—Lord Lansdowne received $500 in gold from a man who said he was the Governor General's agent. Lord Lansdowne gave him $200, but the man never got a cent. The papers demand an investigation.

Judge Monahan has filed an admission of corruption by agents in the Quebec Custom elections.

AMERICAN NEWSPAPER ANNUAL

We have been favored with a copy of N. W. Ayer & Son's American News paper Annual, containing a list of newspapers with it, that we cannot refrain from drawing the attention of our readers to its contents. We believe that it will be of use to any person requiring to ad-
vertise for any purpose in papers away from home, or about to be read by persons whom he knows, that such a com-
pilation contains not only the names of all newspapers and periodicals published in the United States and Canada, but also their advertising rates, while the additional information as to the circulation of each paper serves as a guide to which best adapted for the purpose. The arrange-
ment may be noted as so perfect that the subscriber can easily make his selection in laying the hand on the exact informa-
tion required. From the comparative statement of increase of circulation in the papers, as well as the present amount
